intro: Pedicularis comosa var. asparagoides, commonly known as the asparagus beardtongue, is a flowering plant native to the mountainous regions of central and eastern Europe. It belongs to the family Scrophulariaceae and is characterized by its hairy, glandular stems and lance-shaped leaves. The plant produces clusters of tubular, pink or purple flowers that bloom in late spring to early summer. It thrives in well-drained, rocky soils and is often found in alpine or subalpine habitats. Due to its unique appearance and ecological significance, it is a subject of interest in both botanical research and horticultural cultivation.
